{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Van Thanh Rudd | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1973}} | birth_place = [[Queensland]], [[Australia]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Australian]] | field = [[Contemporary art]] | training = [[Victorian College of the Arts]], [[RMIT University]] in [[Melbourne]] and [[Griffith University]] in [[Brisbane]]. | movement = [[Political satire]], [[street art]], [[conceptual art]] | works = | patrons = | political_party = [[Victorian Socialists]] | influenced by = [[Marxism]], Leninism, Trotskyism, Socialism, Democratic Socialism, Unionism | influenced = | awards = }}
'''Van Thanh Rudd''' (born 1973)<ref>[http://artabase.net/artist/663-van-thanh-rudd Van Thanh Rudd ] ''Artabase,'' 2008. Retrieved 26 June 2009.</ref> is an award winning and controversial [[Australian]] street artist, sculptor, children's book illustrator, former musician and unionist. <ref name= Rudd>{{ cite web | first = Lucy | last = Battersby | date = 23 May 2008 | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/arts/rudd-nephews-artwork-rejected/2008/05/23/1211183064608.html | title = Rudd nephew's artwork rejected | work = Sydney Morning Herald | publisher = Fairfax | accessdate = 7 May 2009}}</ref> He has balanced his twenty year artistic career with labouring jobs in hospitality, warehousing and construction. His political views have drifted toward the revolutionary left since the early 2000s, away from the centrist [[Australian Labor Party]], the party of choice for the Rudd side of the family. He knows very little about his mother's Vietnamese side of the family, most of whom still live in Vietnam. A member of [[Socialist Alternative (Australia)|Socialist Alternative]]<ref>[http://vanthanhrudd.wordpress.com/2012/10/29/on-joining-socialist-alternative/ ….On joining Socialist Alternative.] ''Van Thanh Rudd,'' 29 October 2012. Retrieved 30 October 2012</ref> and electoral party, the [[Victorian Socialist Party|Victorian Socialists]] his artworks contain radical left-wing commentary and positions. He is also a member of construction and maritime union, the [[Construction, Forestry, Maritime, Mining and Energy Union|CFMMEU]] and the newly forming Workers Art Collective with visual artists Sam Wallman, Tia Kass, Niki Minus, Mary Leunig, Sam Davis, SlimOne, with more members to join in the near future. He often uses the name Van T Rudd or Van as a signature on his art as a visual mockery of the popular [[Vans]] clothing company. He is influenced by the theories of [[Karl Marx]], and many other revolutionary activists and artists who have been struggling against the forces of [[capitalism]].
Rudd has been producing art for over twenty years. He was a musician, mostly as a drummer, bass guitarist and keyboardist in bands Cheezlekane (1993 to 2002), Seconds (2001 to 2007) and Granma (2005 to 2006). One of the first protest marches he attended was for Melbourne's public [https://www.greenleft.org.au/content/victorian-transport-workers-strike transport workers in 1997] with his younger brother, Rad. Also with his younger brother, he attended the [[S11 (protest)|large S11 anti-capitalism protests in 2000]] in Melbourne at Crown Casino. In early 2008, preceding the [[Global financial crisis|Global Financial Crisis]], he joined the [[Revolutionary Socialist Party (Australia)|Revolutionary Socialist Party]] (RSP),<ref>[http://melbourne.rsp.org.au/?q=node/20 Art & the capitalist crisis] ''Direct Action,'' 2009. Retrieved 21 June 2009.</ref> which merged into Socialist Alternative in 2013, and contested the seat of [[Division of Lalor|Lalor]] in the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 federal election]] against [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Julia Gillard]],<ref name=voting>{{ cite web | first = Jasmin | last = Lill | date = 13 August 2010 | title = Kevin Rudd's wild nephew takes on Julia Gillard for seat of Lalor | url = http://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/confidential/kevin-rudds-wild-nephew-takes-on-julia-gillard-for-seat-of-lalor/story-e6freq7o-1225904719152 | work = Courier-Mail | publisher = News limited <!-- aka Queensland Newspapers --> | accessdate = 16 August 2010}}</ref><ref name = austory /> generating 0.50% of the vote.<ref name=house>{{ cite web | date = 6 September 2010 | title = House of Representatives, VIC Division - Lalor | work = Australian Electoral Commission | publisher = Commonwealth of Australia | url = http://vtr.aec.gov.au/HouseDivisionFirstPrefs-15508-222.htm | accessdate = 7 September 2010}}</ref> Rudd began drawing cartoons at a young age and was largely self-taught. He nearly failed a humanities course in the early 1990s at [[Griffith University]].<ref>[http://www.van-thanh-rudd.net/content/about-artist About the artist] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922113000/http://www.van-thanh-rudd.net/content/about-artist |date=22 September 2009 }} ''van-thanh-rudd.net''. 2009. Retrieved 26 June 2009.</ref> After several [https://www.van-t-rudd.net/about.html art exhibitions] and playing gigs in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne, he eventually went on to study art at the [[RMIT University]] and [[Victorian College of the Arts]], where he was elected student union representative with socialists Left Action. He was meant to complete a PhD in fine art at the Victorian College of the Arts but ran out of funding and also became fed up with the [[Post-Marxism|post-marxist]] saturation of theory and practise in art.
==Personal life== Rudd was born in [[Nambour]], [[Queensland]],<ref>{{Dead link|date=July 2010}}[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/brushing-up-on-rudds-politics/2007/06/10/1181414139052.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 Brushing up on Rudd's politics] ''The Age,'' 11 June 2007. Retrieved 7 May 2009.</ref> to Vietnam veteran Malcolm Rudd (the brother of Kevin Rudd) and Tuoi,<ref name = austory /><ref>{{ cite web | work = Herald Sun | date = 5 February 2010 | title = Kevin Rudd defends nephew Van Thanh Rudd's right to protest | url = http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/kevin-rudd-defends-nephew-van-thanh-rudds-right-to-protest/story-e6frf7l6-1225827055249 | accessdate = 7 March 2010}}</ref> and now resides in [[Footscray, Victoria|Footscray]], [[Melbourne]].<ref>[http://www.multiculturalarts.com.au/events2007/vanrudd.shtml Van Thanh Rudd: The Carriers, Local Terrain - Visual Arts (kultour)] ''Multicultural Arts Victoria.'' Accessed 7 March 2010.</ref> He has an older brother Dat and younger brother Rad. For many of his younger years, he was involved in numerous creative projects with Rad including film making and acting. As a drummer, Rudd joined a Brisbane-based indie pop-rock band called Cheezlekane in the early 1990s with members Patrick Devery (lead vocals), Cameron Peterson (bass guitar) and Nick Stamford (guitar). They played many pub gigs in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne and gained interest from [[Geffen Records]] in 1998 due to their first 4-track produced album called Knee High Fidelity. With musician friends Iain Wilson, Ritchie Giliberto and Mark Buggy, Rudd formed the band Seconds with his brother Rad as lead singer. He also was a keyboardist in a band called Stalis Vetch with Rad. He has a partner and experienced youth worker of [[Chilean Australian|Chilean heritage]], Tania; daughter, Loyola; and son, Manolo. Rudd says that his deeper, leftist political awakening came after meeting his partner, whose family fled [[Chile]] after General [[Augusto Pinochet]] deposed the elected socialist [[Salvador Allende]] and began violently targeting leftists.<ref name = austory /><ref>[http://www.van-thanh-rudd.net/content/detailed-bio Detailed Bio] ''van-thanh-rudd.net''. Retrieved 7 March 2010.</ref>Tania was an active member of the radical left [[Democratic Socialist Perspective|DSP]] and campaigned for refugee rights. They formed a band called Granma in 2005 with Tania on drums and her brothers Ricardo on keyboards, Nicolas on Vocals, Simon on guitar and Rudd on Bass and vocals. Rudd decided to leave music in 2007 to focus more upon his visual art.
== Finalist in Metro Art Competition (2004) == In 2004 Rudd was selected as a finalist in the 2004 [http://www.metrogallery.com.au/ Metro Art Competition] with a realist-style artwork depicting a combined version of paintings by Albert Tucker and Jeffery Smart .
== The Carriers Project (2004 to 2007) and Controversy == In 2004, as Rudd's paintings became more politicized, he decided that exhibiting his large paintings inside galleries wasn't going to reach large audiences, so he began carrying them in public. He was to call this [http://www.multiculturalarts.com.au/events2007/vanrudd.shtml The Carriers Project]. He entered the project in various festivals based in Melbourne including [[Melbourne Fringe Festival|Fringe]] and later the [[Big West Festival]], and it later culminated in a national tour of Australia through [http://www.multiculturalarts.com.au/events2007/vanrudd.shtml kultour]. Some of his paintings depicting 'exploding terrorists' created unease with authorities in [https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/rudds-nephew-faced-arrest/news-story/a0a23fb65dddda105fec6f7ef0fb1802?sv=d3ff0b7a6fb98b42aac8f6fdf2957d94 Brisbane] and Perth. He claims he was adding valuable commentary about the anti-terror laws in Australia. It was a coincidence that, in 2007, while Rudd was in Perth completing his national tour, that his uncle Kevin Rudd was elected Prime Minister of Australia.
== Pro-Palestinian Artwork Censored in Footscray (2006) == In 2006, Rudd created an artwork called 'Portrait of an Exploding Terrorist'. It was a combined painting and billboard piece in one. He carried the painting around the streets of Melbourne, while exhibiting a large piece on the public billboard at [http://www.trocaderoartspace.com.au/ Trocadero Art Space, Footscray.]It wasn't long before the local council demanded the billboard piece be removed, claiming it constituted litter. Gallery director Michael Brennan and Rudd were forced to remove the piece to avoid paying a large fine. The piece was critical of the State of Israel and argued that it inflicted terror upon the Palestinian people.
==Hugo Chávez mural (2007)== In 2007 Rudd created an artwork depicting a large mural on a gallery wall at Trocadero Art Space in Footscray with signatories of Australians who supported a visit to the country by [[Venezuelan President]] [[Hugo Chávez]]. It was titled "Smells Like Sulphur: A Tribute to Venezuela and the Art of Telling Bush to Piss Off", referencing Chavez' [[UN General Assembly]] speech the previous year, when he called former [[US President]] [[George W. Bush]] "the devil".<ref>[http://www.artshub.com.au/au/news.asp?sId=159968 Controversial petition a work of art] ''Arts Hub,'' 4 June 2007. Retrieved 21 June 2009.</ref>
== Finalist in Sunshine Coast Art Prize (2007) == In 2007, Rudd submitted an oil painting titled '100 000 to 400 000' to the [https://gallery.sunshinecoast.qld.gov.au/Art-Prizes/Sunshine-Coast-Art-Prize Sunshine Coast Art Prize]. The painting was awarded a second prize and artist Tony Albert won the main prize. The local media tried to whip up [https://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/dont-tell-uncle-kev/328769/ controversy] around Rudd's painting because it showed a U.S flag burning.
==Banksy homage (2008)== In 2008 the [[City of Melbourne]] rejected a painting by Rudd depicting [[Ronald McDonald]] setting fire to [[Thích Quảng Đức]] with the Olympic torch. According to Rudd, the artwork was a [[Homage (arts)|homage]] to British [[street art]]ist [[Banksy]] and a comment on [[human rights]] abuses in the run-up to the [[2008 Olympic Games]]. Rudd accused the City of Melbourne of political censorship which they denied, claiming he was solely picked to feature in the [[Ho Chi Minh City]] exhibition for his [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]] heritage.<ref name= Rudd />
==Connex controversy (2009)== In 2009 Rudd made an artwork critical of [[Connex Melbourne|Connex]]'s parent company [[Veolia Environnement]]'s light rail contract which is to link [[Israeli settlement]]s in the [[West Bank]] with [[Jerusalem]]. The artwork was displayed at [[Platform artists group|Platform Artists Group]]'s public gallery, adjacent to [[Flinders Street Station]], a major train station in Melbourne.<ref>{{ cite web | first = Reid |last = Sexton | title = Rudd's nephew clashes with Connex | date = 8 March 2009 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/national/rudds-nephew-clashes-with-connex-20090307-8ryp.html | work = Age | publisher = Fairfax | accessdate = 7 May 2009}}</ref> Connex threatened Rudd with legal action over his use of a similar font and colour-scheme to the company's logo and the [[Anti-Defamation League]] accused the gallery of racism.<ref>{{ cite journal | last = McLennan | first = Azlan | date = 11 March 2009 | title = Connex tries to censor pro-Palestinian art | url = http://www.sa.org.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1929&Itemid=106 | work = Socialist Alternative | issue = 139 | accessdate = 27 June 2010}}</ref> The [[Electronic Intifada]] claimed that Rudd's artwork was a boost to the campaign against Connex and Veolia<ref>{{ cite web | last = Nieuwhof | first = Adri | title = Installation criticizing occupation, Veolia causes stir | work = Electronic Intifada | date = 12 March 2009 | url = http://electronicintifada.net/v2/article10388.shtml | accessdate = 27 June 2010}}</ref> – a part of the general [[Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions]] campaign against [[Israel]] – whose contract to run Melbourne trains expired in November 2009.<ref>[http://boycottconnex.org/petition2 Petition Lyn Kosky] ''Dump Connex,'' 19 March 2009. Retrieved 7 May 2009.</ref>
==Used car part from an Afghan civilian car (2009)== IN 2009 Rudd exhibited in Melbourne a used part from an Afghan civilian car, purportedly destroyed by an [[International Security Assistance Force]] missile in Southern [[Afghanistan]]. It accompanied a price tag of $1.2 billion. Rudd estimated the value based on what he believed was "the astronomical price paid by victims of war". He broke down the multi-trillion dollar US war budget for the [[Middle East]] since 2001 and included other variables such as the cost of wounded civilians and soldiers.<ref>{{ cite web | first = Monique |last = Schafter | title = The story behind a Hungry Beast story | date = 7 October 2009 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/tv/hungrybeast/blog/mschafter/story-behind-hungry-beast-story/index.html | work = Hungry Beast | publisher = ABC | accessdate = 2 November 2012}}</ref>
== Finalist in Sunshine Coast Art Prize (2009) == In 2009, Rudd was again selected as a finalist in the Sunshine Coast Art Prize for the collage called 'Freedom Furniture' which was critical of the U.S.A's [[Operation Enduring Freedom]] by contrasting an image of a U.S marine placing a wounded child of Afghanistan into the sofa of a luxury home in a western lounge room setting from a home wares catalogue.
==Anti-racism protest (2010)== On [[Australia Day]] 2010, Rudd and RSP member, Sam King, dressed in [[Ku Klux Klan]] outfits with the signs "Racism – Made in Australia" in front of the outfits, outside the [[Rod Laver Arena]] during the [[Australian Open]] to protest the refusal of the [[Victorian Government]] to treat the [[Violence against Indians in Australia controversy|attacks on Indians in Victoria]] as racially motivated and also the federal government's policies towards [[asylum seekers]].<ref name = austory /><ref>{{ cite web | first = Selma | last = Milovanovic | date = 26 January 2010 | title = PM's nephew marks 'Invasion Day' with anti-racism protest | url = http://www.theage.com.au/national/pms-nephew-marks-invasion-day-with-antiracism-protest-20100126-mvhj.html | work = The Age | publisher = Fairfax | accessdate = 26 June 2010}}</ref> Rudd and King were arrested within 10 minutes and charged with inciting a riot.<ref name=inciting>{{ cite web | date = 26 January 2010 | title = Rudd's nephew fined for 'inciting riot' | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/01/26/2801852.htm?site=local | accessdate = 26 June 2010}}</ref> Rudd also told the Indian weekly newsmagazine ''[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]'' that the "dominant culture in Australia is a racist culture."<ref>{{ cite web | date= 8 February 2010 | work = Outlook India | publisher = Fully Loaded Magazines | url = http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?264017 | title = The Dominant Culture In Australia Is A Racist Culture | accessdate = 26 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{ cite web | first = Matt | last = Wade | date = 1 February 2010 | work = The Age | publisher = Fairfax | url = http://www.theage.com.au/national/indian-journal-focuses-on-hate-20100131-n6ju.html | title = Indian journal focuses on 'hate' | accessdate = 26 June 2010}}</ref>
==Relationship with Kevin Rudd== In a 2010 interview on [[3AW]], Kevin Rudd expressed to [[Neil Mitchell (radio announcer)|Neil Mitchell]] that he was not a fan of his nephew's political views but supported the notion of [[free speech]] in Australia, adding, "[you] can choose your friends but...".<ref name = austory>{{ cite web | date = 26 January 2010 | title = Kevin Rudd speaks about Van Rudd | work = Neil Mitchell | publisher = 3AW | url = http://www.3aw.com.au/blogs/3aw-generic-blog/kevin-rudd-speaks-about-van-rudd/20100126-mvl3.html | accessdate = 6 March 2010}}</ref> According to a member of the RSP, the PM and his nephew are not in regular contact.<ref name=inciting /> In a later 2010 [[Fairfax Media|Fairfax]] radio interview, on the same subject Kevin Rudd stated: "Do I agree in any way with what he's done? No I don't, absolutely."<ref name = austory>{{ cite web | date = 5 February 2010 | title = Rudd defends artist nephew | publisher = ''Australian Broadcasting Corporation'' | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/02/05/2811160.htm | accessdate = 6 September 2010}}</ref> Rudd was the subject of an episode of [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] program ''[[Australian Story]]'', broadcast in August 2010, which reported his uncle had been invited to appear, but declined.<ref name = austory>{{ cite web | date = 16 August 2010 | title = Our New Selection | work = Australian Story | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | url = http://www.abc.net.au/austory/specials/ourselection/default.htm | accessdate = 23 August 2010}}</ref><ref name = takes-on-gillard-for-lalor>{{ cite web | first = Jasmin | last = Lill | date = 13 August 2010 | title = Kevin Rudd's wild nephew takes on Julia Gillard for seat of Lalor | url = http://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/confidential/kevin-rudds-wild-nephew-takes-on-julia-gillard-for-seat-of-lalor/story-e6freq7o-1225904719152 | work = Courier-Mail | publisher = News limited <!-- aka Queensland Newspapers --> | accessdate = 16 August 2010}}</ref>
==2010 federal election== Rudd contested the seat of [[Division of Lalor|Lalor]] for the [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] in the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 federal election]] against [[Australian Labor Party|Labor]] [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Julia Gillard]]<ref name=voting/> for the unregistered RSP.<ref>{{ cite web | date = 6 September 2010 | title = Lalor, (VIC) Melbourne Outer South-west suburbs | work = ABC Elections | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | url = http://www.abc.net.au/elections/federal/2010/guide/lalo.htm | accessdate = 7 September 2010}}</ref> This signals the RSP's failure to generate the 500-member minimum required by the [[Victorian Electoral Commission]] to register as an official political party.<ref>{{ cite web | year = 2010 | title = About political parties | work = Victorian Electoral Commission | publisher = Commonwealth of Australia | url = http://www.vec.vic.gov.au/Stand/stand-about.html | accessdate = & September 2010}}</ref> He garnered a total of 516 votes, scoring 0.50% of the overall vote, with a +0.50% swing. This placed him as the second least preferred candidate, ahead of [[Regional Australia|regional]] tourism developer, Marc Aussie-Stone, compared to Gillard as first preference, who garnered 66,060 votes, scoring 64.26% of the overall vote, with a +4.37% swing.<ref name=house/> The artist claimed on an ABC radio interview his reason for running in the election was that the appointment of Gillard as PM marked "a more [[conservative]] path for Labor" and that she was "influenced by the [[Mining in Australia|mining]] magnates... [and] the conservative [[Trade union|unions]]".<ref name=attacks>{{ cite web | title = Rudd's nephew attacks Gillard | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | date = 25 June 2010 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/06/25/2937225.htm | accessdate = 26 June 2010}}</ref>
== Artwork Censored from Human Rights Arts Festival (2011) == In 2011, Rudd was asked to submit an artwork for an art exhibition as part of the 2011 [https://2018.hraff.org.au/ Human Rights Arts and Film Festival]. He submitted a large canvas that was a celebration of the [[Arab Spring|Arab Spring (2011)]] on one side, and also a contribution to the [[Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions|BDS campaign]] on the other. The Arab Spring side showed a cartoon-like body exploding with the words 'I'm not a terrorist, I'm just exploding with joy', and the BDS side showed in cartoon style, pop icon [[Justin Bieber|Justine Bieber]] spray painting graffiti on Israel's separation wall. The graffiti depicted [[Max Brenner|Max Brenner Chocolates]] as Bieber announced that he wished he didn't play in Israel because he would be complicit in Israel's occupation of Palestine. Max Brenner was targeted by [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-08-22/brull-the-campaign-against-the-max-brenner-protesters/2847334 BDS campaigners] for its complicity in Israel's occupation of Palestine at around the same period of this art exhibition at No Vacancy Gallery, QV Shopping Centre, Melbourne. But [http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2011/s3216175.htm Rudd's artwork was censored] before it got installed in the gallery. Rudd claimed the gallery directors confronted him in the gallery saying the artwork was violent. Rudd also took part in the anti-Max Brenner protests in the QV building but avoided being arrested. Several other protesters were arrested but later freed from charges in a [https://theconversation.com/is-the-max-brenner-protestors-court-victory-an-australian-legal-watershed-8441 landmark victory.]
== The Rich Forks (1998 to 2018) == One of Rudd's more obscure, mysterious, yet incisive art projects is called the #RichForks. It made news at various outlets around the world. It began over fifteen years ago when Rudd began collecting luxury dinner forks that had just been used by the political and business elites of the world<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://creators.vice.com/en_au/article/kbn5pa/steal-this-fork-artist-15-years|title=Meet the Melbourne Artist who Spent 15 Years Stealing Silverware Used by the 1%|date=2016-05-17|work=Creators|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-au}}</ref>. As a waiter, he was able to get access to the soiled forks and is alleged to have made networks with other hospitality workers internationally in order to appropriate forks from some of the richest people on earth<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/apr/27/crumbs-and-all-prince-harry-hillary-clinton-and-julia-gillard-have-cutlery-swiped-for-exhibition|title=Crumbs and all: Prince Harry, Hillary Clinton and Julia Gillard have cutlery swiped for exhibition|last=Harmon|first=Steph|date=2016-04-27|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hyperallergic.com/295536/artist-skewers-inequality-by-stealing-forks-used-by-the-1/|title=Artist Skewers Inequality by Stealing Forks Used by the 1%|date=2016-05-11|work=Hyperallergic|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.starweekly.com.au/lifestyle/food-for-thought-in-fork-exhibition/|title=Star Weekly {{!}} Forking out for the rich and famous - Star Weekly|website=www.starweekly.com.au|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.willpjk.com/newsfeat/the-rich-forks-exhibition-an-expose-of-those-fed-with-silver-spoons|title=‘The Rich Forks’ exhibition an exposé of those fed with silver spoons|date=2016-04-07|work=William PJ Kulich|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foodandwine.com/blogs/artist-steals-forks-rich-and-famous|title=This Artist Steals Forks of the Rich and Famous|work=Food & Wine|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.crikey.com.au/2016/04/29/thats-forked-up/|title=That's forked up|date=2016-04-29|work=Crikey|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/style/article/forks-exhibition-rudd/index.html|title=I have Prince Harry's fork, by artist V-T-R|date=2016-04-28|work=CNN Style|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en}}</ref>. Rudd claims the whole project is commentary on the massive class divide between struggling workers and wealthy capitalists. There has only been two exhibitions of the #RichForks - [http://footscrayarts.com/event/the-rich-forks/ one in Footscray] and [https://newcastlelive.com.au/tina-2016-celebration-creative-city/ one in Newcastle], Australia. It is not known whether Rudd will continue with this project into the near future.
== Murals for Union Struggles == In 2016, fifty-five [[Carlton & United Breweries]] maintenance workers in Abbottsford, Victoria, were sacked then re-employed on individual contracts with an overall 65% wage cut<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/business/workplace/staff-picket-cub-factory-as-sackings-stall-production-20160712-gq3zsx.html|title=Carlton United Breweries: Staff picket CUB factory as sackings stall beer production|last=Toscano|first=Nick|date=2016-07-12|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>. When one of the organisers from the Electrical Trades Union made a call-out on social media for a street artist to paint a mural on a shipping container. Rudd jumped at the chance and painted an iconic murals at the site of their nine month protest. One of the murals, painted on the side of a shipping container, shows a large unionist's arm pulling aside the shipping container wall revealing the CUB boss stealing bags of money<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.van-t-rudd.net/street-murals.html|title=Street Murals|website=www.van-t-rudd.net|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>. Another shipping container at the Abbottsford site depicted horses appropriated from the CUB logo, only this time they were dying of thirst in drought conditions (i.e. Carlton Drought).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.van-t-rudd.net/street-murals.html|title=Street Murals|website=www.van-t-rudd.net|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>The protest and boycott by the unionists and workers eventually achieved an important victory<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/dec/07/cub-55-workers-have-won-all-demands-in-industrial-dispute-says-union|title=CUB 55 workers have won all demands in industrial dispute, says union|last=Knaus|first=Christopher|date=2016-12-07|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>. After the #CUB55 protests, the murals were transported to the [[Construction, Forestry, Maritime, Mining and Energy Union|CFMMEU]] training centre in Port Melbourne. It wasn't long before they were used again, and transported to the striking workers at the Longford Gas Plant, Gippsland. Similar to the CUB55, about 200 workers were threatened with the sack if they didn't sign up to a different contract on significantly lower wages and conditions<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-06-22/unions-launch-blockade-at-esso-longford-gas-plant-gippsland/8641744|title=Workers launch protest at Esso gas plant in Gippsland|date=2017-06-22|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-08-28|language=en-AU}}</ref>. Rudd also created a new mural for the protest site which showed an Exxon boss atop a gas platform, sinking workers deeper into the water while smoking a cigar from the gas flare<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.van-t-rudd.net/street-murals.html|title=Street Murals|website=www.van-t-rudd.net|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>. Rudd has since created a series of murals for the car park of the Electrical Trades Union office in North Melbourne with fellow artist and radical left unionist Azlan McLennan. In 2017, he also created a large mural commemorating the CUB55 victory in the car park at [[Victorian Trades Hall]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.van-t-rudd.net/street-murals.html|title=Street Murals|website=www.van-t-rudd.net|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>. In early 2018, Rudd created a mural for the striking waterside workers at Cube<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.van-t-rudd.net/street-murals.html|title=Street Murals|website=www.van-t-rudd.net|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref>
